quiz.title: Unit 3: Relative Motion (Quiz 12)
quiz.subtitle: Relative Motion and Frames of Reference (10 Questions)
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which of the following best defines a 'Frame of Reference' in the context of kinematics?
options: A physical box or vehicle that an observer must be inside to see motion.
The absolute physical center of the universe from which all distances are measured.
The force that causes an object to change its state of motion.
A set of axes and a clock used to measure the positions and velocities of objects.
questions.explanation: A frame of reference is a coordinate system (axes) and a clock used to measure positions and velocities.

questions.question: What is the primary characteristic of an 'Inertial Frame' of reference?
options: It is moving at a constant velocity with no acceleration.
It is accelerating at a constant rate.
It is a frame where fictitious forces like centrifugal force are required.
It is always at rest relative to the Earth's surface.
questions.explanation: Inertial frames have zero acceleration and move at constant velocity.

questions.question: According to the relative velocity notation, if $V_{AB}$ is the velocity of object A relative to object B, which equation is correct?
Two cars are driving toward each other on a straight road. Car A is moving at +20 m/s and Car B is moving at −15 m/s. What is the approach speed (magnitude of relative velocity)?
Which of the following requires the use of 'fictitious forces' to explain motion?
questions.explanation: Fictitious forces (like centrifugal force) appear in accelerating non-inertial frames.

questions.question: If Car A moves at 20 m/s East and Car B moves at 15 m/s East, what is the velocity of Car A relative to Car B ($V_{AB}$)?

A river flows due East at $6.0\text{ m/s}$. A motorboat, which can travel at $10.0\text{ m/s}$ in still water, is steered due North. What is the magnitude and direction of the boat's velocity relative to an observer on the North bank?

A boatman wants to cross a $100\text{ m}$ wide river (flowing East) by the shortest possible path. If the river velocity is $3\text{ m/s}$ and his boat speed in still water is $5\text{ m/s}$, in which direction should he point the boat?
questions.explanation: To cancel downstream drift: $5\sin\theta = 3$ ⇒ $\sin\theta = 0.6$ ⇒ $\theta = 36.9^\circ$ West of North.

questions.question: A swimmer can swim at $2\text{ m/s}$ in still water. She heads due North across a river flowing due East at $1.5\text{ m/s}$. If the river is $80\text{ m}$ wide, at what cardinal position relative to her starting point does she land on the North bank?
questions.explanation: Time to cross = $80/2 = 40$ s. Drift = $1.5 \times 40 = 60$ m East.

questions.question: An airplane flies with an airspeed of $200\text{ km/h}$. A wind is blowing from the West at $50\text{ km/h}$. To reach a destination due North of its starting point, the pilot must head the plane:
questions.explanation: Wind from West means wind blows East. To go due North, plane must point into the wind (West of North).

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You've mastered relative motion and frames of reference.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! Review the difference between inertial and non-inertial frames.
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing. Focus on relative velocity addition and river crossing problems.
scoreMessages.0: Let's review. Study how velocities add in different reference frames.
